sourceDesc:
<<<<<<< HEAD
The royall entertainment of the King, by the Royalists of Huntington. Being a true relation of the great joy of that town at his comming, with their bountifull gifts to welcome him thither. Also his tender care of them exprest by proclamation to keep them free from plunder; and his extraordinary favour and mercy in setting all the prisoners free. Together with the great lamentation of the inhabitants at his departure. Sent in a letter by a person of credit, to a gentleman of worth in London. J. W.
8 p.
Printed by John Macock., London, : 1645.
A person of credit = J.W., who has signed page 8. Anti-Royalist. Annotation on Thomason copy: "Septemb: 1st". Reproduction of the original in the British Library.
=======
The royall entertainment of the King, by the Royalists of Huntington. Being a true relation of the great joy of that town at his comming, with their bountifull gifts to welcome him thither. Also his tender care of them exprest by proclamation to keep them free from plunder; and his extraordinary favour and mercy in setting all the prisoners free. Together with the great lamentation of the inhabitants at his departure. Sent in a letter by a person of credit, to a gentleman of worth in London. J. W.
8 p.
Printed by John Macock., London, : 1645.
A person of credit = J.W., who has signed page 8. Anti-Royalist. Annotation on Thomason copy: "Septemb: 1st". Reproduction of the original in the British Library.
John Macock.
